DataElement.longName: Therapeutic Procedure Pharmacologic Substance or Chemical NCI Thesaurus Name
DataElement.definition: A term describing a therapeutic agent as captured in the Pharmacological Substance (C1909) or Drug or Chemical by Structure (C1913) branch of the National Cancer Institute Thesaurus (NCIt) hierarchy tree.
DataElement.administrativeNotes: 6/24/24 Add CRDC Alt name/Def, CSI.  Released and upd RS to Standard. jk 4/29/24 created by ref CDE for CRDC Std request; Ped gps use CDE  13579886 Therapeutic Procedure Agent Name. jk

DataElementConcept.longName: Therapeutic Procedure Pharmacologic Substance or Chemical
DataElementConcept.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter or stop a pathologic process.:Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances._Substances that are grouped or classified by chemical composition.
DataElementConcept.administrativeNotes: 6/24/24 Released and upd RS to Qualified. jk

ObjectClass.definition: An action or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process.

Concepts.definition: Medical care intended to treat or cure a condition or lessen its symptoms. This includes the administration of drugs, surgical procedures, physical or psychotherapy, or the use of therapeutic devices.

Property.longName: Pharmacologic Substance Drug or Chemical by Structure
Property.definition: Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances._Substances that are grouped or classified by chemical composition.

Concepts.definition: Substances that are grouped or classified by chemical composition.

Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances.

ConceptualDomain.definition: Any specific activity undertaken during the course of a clinical study or research protocol.

ValueDomain.longName: NCI Thesaurus Pharmacologic Substance or Chemical Name
ValueDomain.definition: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) reference terminology and ontology.  NCI Thesaurus (NCIt) provides controlled terminology for clinical care, translational and basic research, public dissemination of information and associated administrative activities. NCIt is updated monthly to support precise coding of data based on the most recent developments in the cancer and biomedical research community.  NCIt has rich textual and formal logic descriptions of biomedical concepts, including full text definitions, synonyms, a true is_a taxonomic structure, polyhierarchy, inferred partonomy, and other features that make it suitable for supporting accurate human understanding and complex computer processing.  NCIt has been produced by NCI Enterprise Vocabulary Services (EVS) since 1997, and adopted since then for use by numerous federal agencies, standards development and research organizations._Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances._Substances that are grouped or classified by chemical composition._The words or language units by which a thing is known.
ValueDomain.administrativeNotes:
7/15/24 Upd PV to point to concept in hierarchy, not just to the concept. mr; 
6/24/24 upd VD max length to 200, released and upd RS to Qualified; resolved by-ref PV tool semantics. jk;  5/17/24 Upd PVs to be the link to C2991 and C1909. mr

ValueMeaning.definition: Not characterized in any other way.

Concepts.definition: Not characterized in any other way.

ValueMeaning.definition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.
ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes: 3/4/25 Added alt VM names per RFC 26 CR 1. sl

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.administrativeNotes:
3/4/25 Added alt VM names per RFC 26 CR 1. sl;
10/10/23 changed Long Name from "Not Stated" to match NCIt Preferred name and current caDSR concept Long Name of "Not Reported" per Brenda.Janice . LS

ValueMeaning.definition: The National Cancer Institute (NCI) reference terminology and ontology.  NCI Thesaurus (NCIt) provides controlled terminology for clinical care, translational and basic research, public dissemination of information and associated administrative activities. NCIt is updated monthly to support precise coding of data based on the most recent developments in the cancer and biomedical research community.  NCIt has rich textual and formal logic descriptions of biomedical concepts, including full text definitions, synonyms, a true is_a taxonomic structure, polyhierarchy, inferred partonomy, and other features that make it suitable for supporting accurate human understanding and complex computer processing.  NCIt has been produced by NCI Enterprise Vocabulary Services (EVS) since 1997, and adopted since then for use by numerous federal agencies, standards development and research organizations._Any natural, endogenously-derived, synthetic or semi-synthetic compound with pharmacologic activity. A pharmacologic substance has one or more specific mechanism of action(s) through which it exerts one or more effect(s) on the human or animal body. They can be used to potentially prevent, diagnose, treat or relieve symptoms of a disease. Formulation specific agents and some combination agents are also classified as pharmacologic substances.

The National Cancer Institute (NCI) reference terminology and ontology.  NCI Thesaurus (NCIt) provides controlled terminology for clinical care, translational and basic research, public dissemination of information and associated administrative activities. NCIt is updated monthly to support precise coding of data based on the most recent developments in the cancer and biomedical research community.  NCIt has rich textual and formal logic descriptions of biomedical concepts, including full text definitions, synonyms, a true is_a taxonomic structure, polyhierarchy, inferred partonomy, and other features that make it suitable for supporting accurate human understanding and complex computer processing.  NCIt has been produced by NCI Enterprise Vocabulary Services (EVS) since 1997, and adopted since then for use by numerous federal agencies, standards development and research organizations.

ConceptualDomain.definition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.
